titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Oran Arabic
titleStmt.author: Aleksandra Ercegovčević

div.p: Oran is a major coastal city in northwest Algeria. It is the second-largest city of the country and was founded at the beginning of the 10th century by Andalusian merchants as a base for trade with the North African hinterland: it developed commercially because of its sea connections with Europe.

Oran is divided into the waterfront district and, formerly divided by a ravine, old and a new quarters. The old Spanish-Arab-Ottoman town, called La Blanca, lies on a hill west of the ravine. The new town, called La Ville Nouvelle and built by the French after 1831, occupies the terraces on the east bank of the ravine. La Blanca is crowned by the Ottoman-Turkish citadel, which was modified by the Spanish and the French and re-named Santa Cruz.
The dialect of Oran is a mainly Bedouin-based urban dialect. Oran is a melting pot of Hilāli rural varieties from the region which are mixed, to a lesser extent, with some pre-Hilali varieties.

Cantineau (1940) is a succinct article on the dialects of the area of the former French “Département d’Oran” and includes information on the dialect of Oran itself. Siagh (1976) deals with the phonological system of the dialect of Oran, presenting minimal pairs for every phoneme. Bouhadiba (1990) discusses phonotactic constraints and syllablic structural conditions in the vernacular of Oran. Guerrero (2015) is a concise introduction to the dialect of Oran, describing its main phonetic, morpho-syntactic, and lexical features, and comparing and contrasting its Bedouin and sedentary features. Guerrero (2016) offers a phonetic sketch of the dialect of Oran, including topics like phonological neutralization, phonetic changes, and syllablic structures.
The CORVAM corpus of Maghrebi varieties includes a sketch of the dialect's main linguistic features and a list of bibliographical references.
CORVAM also includes one audio file in Oran Arabic with transcription and Spanish translation.
